headline.main: How Exercise Can Strengthen the Brain

docs.abstract: For the first time scientists showed that, in mice at least, exercise spurs the development of mitochondria in brain cells and may make the brain more fit, similar to the way exercise makes muscles stronger.
docs.snippet: For the first time scientists showed that, in mice at least, exercise spurs the development of mitochondria in brain cells and may make the brain more fit, similar to the way exercise makes muscles stronger.

docs.lead_paragraph: Can exercise make the brain more fit? That absorbing question inspired a new study at the University of South Carolina during which scientists assembled mice and assigned half to run for an hour a day on little treadmills, while the rest lounged in their cages without exercising.

headline.main: How Exercise Can Strengthen the Brain

docs.abstract: For the first time scientists showed that, in mice at least, exercise spurs the development of mitochondria in brain cells and may make the brain more fit, similar to the way exercise makes muscles stronger.
docs.snippet: For the first time scientists showed that, in mice at least, exercise spurs the development of mitochondria in brain cells and may make the brain more fit, similar to the way exercise makes muscles stronger.

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicine might never have achieved its greatest triumph to date — eradicating smallpox — if small errors had not been made in a measles immunization program.

headline.seo: Small Fixes: How a Failure With Measles Helped to Eradicate Smallpox
headline.main: How Tiny Errors in Africa Led to a Global Triumph
headline.print_headline: Tiny Errors Led to a Global Triumph

docs.lead_paragraph: The goal of circumcising 20 million men in 14 African countries by 2015 is slowly progressing; less than 3 percent have been circumcised so far.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite political upheaval in Thailand, basic medical treatment and disease prevention are on the upswing in the kingdom’s remote corners.

docs.lead_paragraph: In Mozambique, groups of AIDS patients are using a simple new system to be sure they get their lifesaving antiretroviral drugs: taking turns traveling to collect a supply of pills.

headline.main: An Aid Worker Writes: Hope and Exasperation at a Kandahar Hospital

docs.abstract: Today, in the cacophonous wards of Mirwais Hospital in Kandahar, Afghanistan, there are more victims of traffic accidents than there are war wounded.  That says a lot.
docs.snippet: Today, in the cacophonous wards of Mirwais Hospital in Kandahar, Afghanistan, there are more victims of traffic accidents than there are war wounded.  That says a lot.

docs.lead_paragraph: Each time I walk along Mirwais's crowded corridors, or visit the wards bustling with mothers and sick children, it is a new experience. No two visits are ever the same. There are more patients, more anxious mothers, more men gathered in gossiping groups on the stairwells; more prayer beads turning, more busy staff, more noise.

headline.main: An Aid Worker Writes: Hope and Exasperation at a Kandahar Hospital

docs.abstract: Today, in the cacophonous wards of Mirwais Hospital in Kandahar, Afghanistan, there are more victims of traffic accidents than there are war wounded. That says a lot.
docs.snippet: Today, in the cacophonous wards of Mirwais Hospital in Kandahar, Afghanistan, there are more victims of traffic accidents than there are war wounded. That says a lot.

docs.lead_paragraph: Perhaps you've heard of the "damage is done" scenario. An elderly family member started smoking as a young person, maybe a teenager, tucking a pack of cigarettes into his rolled-up shirtsleeve or into her purse. Decades later, despite wall-to-wall anti-smoking ads, despite smoking being outlawed in nearly every public space, perhaps despite family pleas or doctors' admonitions or even a heart attack, that person remains a smoker.
docs.abstract: Recent research suggests even older smokers benefit from quitting.
docs.snippet: Recent research suggests even older smokers benefit from quitting.

headline.main: For Many, a Life-Saving Drug Out of Reach

docs.abstract: Deaths by overdose could be cut dramatically if Naloxone were available over the counter and placed in every first aid kit.
docs.snippet: Deaths by overdose could be cut dramatically if Naloxone were available over the counter and placed in every first aid kit.
